item.title: Paul Givan told he must resign as NI first minister
item.description: Days after he got the role, the Democratic Unionist Party MLA is told he will have to resign when a new leader takes over.

item.title: Scotland fans clean up London after Euro celebrations
item.description: Fans took part in a clean-up of Leicester Square which was covered in litter during celebrations.

item.title: Daniel Morgan case: I don't accept Met's apology - son says
item.description: He tells of his anger after a report calls the force "institutionally corrupt" in its handling of Morgan's murder.

item.title: Mosh pits and no masks at Download Festival pilot
item.description: This weekend's Download Festival is part of a live event trial to see if large-scale gatherings are possible.

item.title: Iran election: Hardliner Raisi will become president
item.description: Cleric Ebrahim Raisi, Iran's top judge, wins victory in election seen as engineered to help him win.

item.title: Chesham and Amersham by-election defeat a warning shot, says Tory co-chairman
item.description: Planning reforms for England and HS2 rail had dominated campaigning in Chesham and Amersham.

item.title: Man looking for Mayfair 'guardian angel' who saved his life
item.description: A woman helped Mathew O'Toole while he was suffering from a stroke in Wigmore Street, Mayfair.

item.title: Robert Schuman: Pope puts father of modern Europe on sainthood path
item.description: The Pope recognises the "heroic virtues" of Robert Schuman, who founded key European institutions.

item.title: Fears Liverpool may lose World Heritage status
item.description: Figures from politics and football urge Unesco not to strip the city of the prestigious status.

item.title: Give people the right to switch off after work - Labour
item.description: The party also says people should have the right to flexible practices, such as working from home.

item.title: Fake ads on Facebook spoil real life fairy story
item.description: A firm making wire fairy sculptures has been hit by scammers using adverts on the social media network.

item.title: Fashion: Suffolk influencers promote self-love with mid-size trends
item.description: Two midsize fashion influencers speak out about the importance of body positivity on social media.

item.title: Week in pictures: 12 - 18 June 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Myanmar: Who are the ethnic armies training protesters?
item.description: Many protesters are being trained by ethnic armed groups - can they eventually topple the junta?

item.title: Juneteenth: After decades, Opal Lee finally gets her day off
item.description: Opal Lee campaigned for years for a national holiday to commemorate the end of slavery in the US.

item.title: Squirrel's sinking feeling as Ipswich gardener thwarts food theft
item.description: Petroleum jelly stops a slippery customer from nabbing an easy lunch.

item.title: Download Pilot Festival: Rock and metal event returns post-Covid
item.description: Rock and metal fans are dusting off their devil horns for the first Download Festival in two years.

item.title: Euro 2020: Christian Eriksen portrait made with Rubik's cubes
item.description: David Wright uses 500 of the colourful 3D puzzlers to create a likeness of the Danish footballer.

item.title: North Korea: Why doesn't it have enough food this year?
item.description: The country's leader Kim Jong-un has warned of shortages - what do we know about the food situation?

item.title: 'My window visit helped save my son’s life after kidney failure'
item.description: Luke Horne was self-isolating because he thought he had Covid - but his dad spotted something else was wrong.

item.title: 'I trained for a 1,000-mile cycle on chemotherapy'
item.description: Terminally ill Gaz Emmerson is cycling the length of Great Britain to raise money for others with sarcoma.

item.title: Ipswich: 'It's surprising we have the lowest Covid rate'
item.description: Why does Ipswich have the lowest coronavirus figures in England?

item.title: Timothy Spall: 'I was crying, swearing and chucking paint'
item.description: He's played Lowry and Turner, and now the actor explains how he came to be holding his own art show.

item.title: France's Le Pen on track for regional power with an eye on presidency
item.description: France's far-right National Rally party looks set to top Sunday's first round regional vote.

item.title: Can old traditions and tech help Singapore reach zero waste?
item.description: Singapore sees its traditional rag and bone collectors as key to its sustainability plans.

item.title: Griezmann saves France but Hungary earn famous point in raucous Budapest
item.description: Antoine Griezmann rescues a point for France and denies Hungary one of the big Euros shocks in front of a raucous 60,000 crowd in Budapest.

item.title: Verstappen beats Hamilton to pole at French Grand Prix
item.description: Red Bull's Max Verstappen took an impressive pole position ahead of title rival Lewis Hamilton's Mercedes at the French Grand Prix.

item.title: England 0-0 Scotland: 'Real hope for Scotland but a wake-up call for England'
item.description: England and Scotland could not be separated as they met once more in a major men's tournament, but all the plaudits must go to Steve Clarke's side, writes Phil McNulty.

item.title: Scotland hold England to earn deserved draw
item.description: Both defences were in top form as England and Scotland were unable to break the deadlock in their Euro 2020 Group D match at Wembley.

item.title: England 0-0 Scotland - how the internet reacted to their Wembley stalemate
item.description: England v Scotland ended 0-0 and the Scottish fans might feel happier. Here's how it all unfolded online.

item.title: Euro 2020: How Scotland's 'colossal' Billy Gilmour dominated at Wembley
item.description: BBC Sport pundits Danny Murphy and Charlie Adam praise the performance of Billy Gilmour in Scotland's 0-0 draw against England

item.title: Euro 2020: 'One step closer to qualification' - but why did England 'lack ideas' against Scotland?
item.description: Captain Harry Kane says England are one step closer to the last 16 at Euro 2020, but did they lack ideas in draw with Scotland?

item.title: England v Scotland: The fans who lost their Euro 2020 tickets
item.description: Some fans are having to make new plans after their tickets were cancelled.

item.title: Yes Sir, I Can Boogie: Why disco hit is now Scotland's unofficial anthem
item.description: The 1970s disco classic has become the country's unofficial anthem ahead of the match with England.

item.title: England 0-0 Scotland: Andy Robertson says 'make sure it's not a pointless result'
item.description: Captain Andy Robertson has urged Scotland to make sure their battling goalless draw with England is not a "pointless result" as they bid to make history at Euro 2020.

item.title: Euro 2020: Scotland v England at Euro 1996 and what life was like then
item.description: As the Euro 2020 game looms, what was life like last time the rivals met in a major tournament?

item.title: England 2-0 Scotland: What was it like to be on the receiving end of Paul Gascoigne's genius?
item.description: Paul Gascoigne's brilliant Euro 96 goal is one of English football's most famous moments but it meant a defeat at Wembley which is still hard to swallow for Scotland.

item.title: Ros Atkins On… How the Delta variant took hold in the UK
item.description: Ros Atkins traces back the story of the Delta variant and how it delayed the UK’s reopening plans.

item.title: Covid: What are the care home visiting rules?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to people who want to go to see their loved ones.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Coronavirus restrictions are staying in place because of concerns about the Delta variant.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over 40s in England and Scotland can have their second dose after eight weeks instead of 12.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 42 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now available for younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Coronavirus G7: Could a billion more vaccines for poorer countries make a difference?
item.description: How much difference could the G7 offer of a billion vaccines make to tackling the pandemic?

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions is being delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid: Is there a limit to how much worse variants can get?
item.description: The coronavirus has changed and changed again, getting more transmissible each time.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.
